TUESDAY, JANUARY 9, 1906.

div.head: RUSSIA 'S Finances.
div.p: Oat telegrams contain an account of an interview with the ex-Minister if Russian Finance. The interview took place at Paris and was as favourable in its outlook as could be expected. But even if a stable Govern- ment be re established, a serious deficit in he revenue is inevitable, although it does not appear that there is any danger off the suspension of payments yet awhile, Ao cording to the last return of the Russian State Bank, that institution had credits abroad amounting to 276,300,COO roubles, and held foreign bills for a total of 19,200,000 roubles. These two sums are equal to about £31,000,000, and unless an attempt, which is not considered likely, is made to withdraw these balances rom abroad there are sufficient resources out- side Russia to meet the interest on the na- tional debt proper for fully twelve months. The debt-charge for the year prior to the outbreak of the war was set down in the budget at 290,966,000 roubles, or about £30,600,000, not including the contingent interest on railway bonds nor the ser vice of the mortgage bonds of the Bank of the Nobility ; and although there have sines been further borrowings to the extent of about £100,000,000, the country has other funds available more than sufficient to meet the additional interest required. For instance, although the amount cannot be exactly ascer- tained, it is estimated in the best-informed quarters that the Treasury has about £7,000,000 in gold abroad, while the State Bank's stook of gold in St. Petersburg stoodatover£80,000,000 in the last return. It is true that the latter cannot be disposed of without depriving the note issue of its metallic backing, but, as has been shown,the gold abroad and foreign credits some to £38,000,000, without reckoning the gold store in 8t.Petersburg. That the amor- tisation of the debt might be suspended, and that the tax upon coupons, other than those of the National Debt proper, might be raised con siderably—these are both possibilities if not probabilities in the near future. But remem- bering that Russia, in the face of most adverse ciroumstanoes, has always in the past continned to honour her engagements abroad, and that Spain, with ar smaller resources, kept complete faith with the foreign holders of her debt during the war with the United States, the idea of default need not be taken seriously at present

Of course these considerations are only based on the present outlook. For the moment the struggle has ended in the victory of the reac- tionaries with the help of the troops, and Count Witte declares that he is convicoed that Russia will emerge rejuvenated from the crisis, but even assuming that the advocates of reaction do not misuse their power and compel the people to again resort to extremes, it is obvious that the entire system, political as well as financial, will have to be fundamentally chang- ed if ruin is to be postponed. The economic condition of the Empire has for a long time past been going from bad to worse, and the narrow margin between tolerable and intolerable suffering has at last been wiped out. Unless immediate steps are taken, the anarchic conditions prevailing throughout the whole country will hurry the empire to economic ruin. But there is a precedent in Egypt for an unexpected and complete re- oovery from utter financial collapse, and there is no valid reason why Russia should not even at this—the eleventh hour— be able to emerge as successfully as this country has done from a colossal national bankruptcy. No nation, and least of all a great and proud nation like Russia, lightly incurs the ignominy of bankruptcy, and the more probable result of a firm stand by Western capitalists would be that the Tsar and his advisers would takes radical steps to set their house in order. Peace abroad, tar- reaching political reforms at home, and a system of rigid financial retrenchment would in course of time put a very different complexion on the national balance-sheet. The immense resources of the Empire are no fairy tale, and even the products of Russian agriculture might easily be trebled, and that without any strain, were the problem treated with adequate intelligence and in a spirit of prudent self-sacrifice. For these purposes, no doubt, further large loans would be required, for the mischief lies deep and cannot be cured in a few years ; but such loans would in the end prove a really excellent investment, for not only would they be well secured in themselves but they would give the existing debt a re* and solid basis, founded not on market rigging and statistical jugglery, but on the restored solvency of the Empire.

div.head: Small Dance.
div.p: There will be a email dance at the National Hotel tomorrow at 9.30 p.m.

div.head: Kasr-el-Ali Palace.
div.p: It is confidently stated at Cairo that the Kasr-el-Ali Palace has been sold for L.E. 600,000.
Judicial Commission.
The International Judicial Commission meets at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Cairo, on the 12th inst.
Merchant Seamen's Home.
The annual New Year's Treat at this Home will be given on the 25th nut., and not the 26th, as wrongly announced.
Khedivial Hotel.
On Saturday next (New Year's Eve 0. S.) a small dance will be given at the New Khedi vial Hotel, beginning at 10 p.m.
An Exile.
The Constantinople Criminal Court has or- dered the arrest of a person of the name of Abdallah, who has taken refuge in Egypt, on the ground of his having disturbed the public peace.
Change of Address.
Messrs. Oranstein and Koppel have transfer- red their offices in Cairo to Chareh Mada- begh (Immeuble Coronel), near the National Bank, and their Alexandria offices to 5, me Porte Rosette.
Death from intoxication.
A native of Kafrat el-Arab, near Alexandria, aged 66, was found dead yesterday near the Mafrouza Canal. The inquest subsequently held showed that death was due to excessive indulgence in intoxicants.
Financial Circular.

Messrs. H. de Vries and Boutigny, stock and share brokers, Cairo, publish daily a detailed report of the stock market This circular, which also contains a great deal of financial information, is sent gratis on application.
Opera Season.

The opera season at Alexandria ends to-night with a repetition of La Dogaressa, and com mences in Cairo on Thursday, when the Italian opera company will make its debut at the Khedivial Opera House with Fedora.
Salt at Alexandria.

There has been a phenomenal demand for Balt since the beginning of the year at the shoonah of the Egyptian Salt and Soda Com- pany, and the company is unable to cope with the demand as all the dealers kept back their orders until January l,when the reduced tariff came into force. Salt in packets baa not been obtainable since the beginning of the year.
Mohamedan Advocates in Ceylon.

A meeting attended by 30,000 Mohamedans was held in Ceylon on New Year's Day, at which a resolution was adopted that King Edward should be asked to withdraw the order of the local Supreme Court disallowing Mohamedan advocates to plead with the head covered, and to permit them to enjoy the same privilege as their co religionists in other countries under His Majesty's rule.

div.head: NOTES FROM DAMANHOUR.
div.p: It may not be generally known that in the moudirieh here there is a store, where all the confiscated firearms are kept. Most of those arms are those that have been taken from murderers and other criminals, and among them there are some really good weapons. Any fellah who chooses may, by the payment of a small backshish, have a useless gun changed for a good one from the store. Now this is a positive fact, as I know personally several men who have done this. The authorities ought to put a distinctive stamp on these weapons and thus make it impossible for the man in charge to change them.

We have been having very bad weather here lately. The condition of Damanhonr's streets in rainy weather is indescribable, and the poor horses who have to drag a cart laden with cotton-bags from the station to the ginning mills and vice versa are much to be pitied ! in there times. The cart wheels are embedded in the mod and the poor animal is beaten unmercifully by its driver ; but if the S. F. C. A. cannot do anything in Alexandria what can it do in Damanhour?

There was a fire in Damanhour yesterday and a street water part was sent to extinguish the dames. What with the and almost knee deep and the efforts of one poor mule which was drawing the cart, the "brigade" only arrived on the scene after the fire had spent itself out, but "It is better late than never."
LASSAVE'S.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: ACCESSION DAY. YESTERDAY'S REVIEW. THE CELEBRATIONS IN CAIRO.
div.p: Whatever may be said of the Egyptian soldier as a fighting animal—and the Sudan campaigns have shown that he possesses no small aptitude for war under leaders whom he trusts,—there can be no two opinions about his appearance on the parade-ground. Tall, broad chested, and healthy, neatly and pictu- resquely uniformed, he marches, dresses, and wheels with Teutonic precision and thorough ness. Nor is there anything too mechanical in his movements : the combination of British and Turkish methods has made bis drill; superb without aiming at the too rigid or uni- formity or the absurd parade march—better known as the goose step—that finds such favour at Berlin.

Yesterday's review was a pleasure to watch. The weather was bright and warm, the police arrangements admirable, the troops at their best, and residents and visitors were in great force on the parade-ground. Despite the numbers present the carriage enclosure was by no means uncomfortably fall by 3.15 pm., when the strains of the Khedivial hymn opened the review. The troops were drawn up in line facing the enclosure and the Khe- divial Standard. Infantry on the left, and on the extreme right the Cavalry Band, while the cadets, galloping Maxims, and mule batteries formed the centre and right centre of the line.
Khedive's Inspection

Mounted on bis splendid white Arab, and followed by the principal officers of the Cairo garrison, the Khedive inspected the lines and then riding back took his stand under the great red and white flag while the troops went past him. The cavalry of the Body-Gaurd led at a walk, then came the Maxims and Artillery, then the cadets and Infantry marched past by in companies. The men passed the saluting point! in fine style and once past the Infactry turned and came back in company columns ; one had only to watch the tarbushes and the fixed bayonets to see how steadily they marched. Then came the turn of the Cavalry, who passed the saluting point at the trot, returning later at the canter to the music of "Bonnie Dundee." The Infantry wen* past again in line of three battalions, masted quarter column, and then wheeling and fronting towards the standard advanced, baited, and gave the triple salute "Effendimiz chok yasha."

We understand that H H. the Khedive was extremely gratified with the appearance and drill of the troops and was pleased to express to Lewa Matchett Bey, who was in command, his thorough appreciation of their performance. The Reception.

Yesterday's reception at Abdeen Palace was largely attended. Hosts of functionaries and notables were received by H. H. the Khedive with his usual affability, and all the Princes of the Khedivial House present in Cairo congratulated their ruler on the 12th anniversary of his accession.

Decorations were in great evidence in Cairo, flags of all nations flying every where, and after dusk the Esbekieh Gardens, the Opera-square, the National Bank, and many other buildings were illuminated ; and though the evening was a trifle foggy the general effect was moat bril- liant. The fete in the gardens went on as merrily as usual. Everyone seemed to be enjoying him- self, the strayed reveller was conspicuous by his absence and the Cairenes kept holiday, admired strong men and acrobats, gave ear to all kinds of music, and indulged in cigarettes and coffee with their unusual cheery good humour.
A gala performance of Aiglon at the Opera drew a crowded house and the streets were alive with people till all hours.
At Al Azhar.

The anniversary of the Khedive's accession was celebrated yesterday evening at the ' Ronak El sbbassi" of A1 Azhar University, where a large number of ulema were assem- bled. The Rector of Al Azhar delivered a con- gratulatory speech, hoping that his Highness would have a happy, long, and glorious life. The Governor of Alexandria held a largely attended "zikr" at his private residence yes- terday evening.

The Moslem Benevolent Society of Alexandria, "El-Erwat El Woska," sent its band, composed of 130 pupils and teachers to Cairo, where it took part in the celebrations. The State Railways Administration provided the necessary accommodation for the party for half fares. The band played at the head of the native school pupils in Cairo, who formed a long procession and marched yesterday even- ing from the Esbekieh Gardens to Abdeen, bearing torches.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA DOCTORS' FEES. OFFICIAL STATEMENT. THE DOCTORS' STANDPOINT.
div.p: We have received the following communica- tion from the Alexandria Medical Association, (Ordre des Medecins d'Alexandria) on the subject of the new tariff of doctors' fees Monsieur le Directeur, Les commentaires qu'a provoques l'e'evation des honoraires me- dicaux rendent une reponse explicative neces- saire.

L'Ordre des Medecins d'AIexandrie n'a pas songe a fixer un chiffre d'honoraires invariable; il n'a eu en vue que d'etablir une base propor- tionnelle et legitimee par le rencherissement de la vie materielle et la prosperite geuerale du pays.

Il est parfaitement entendu que -chaque praticien agira suivant cette indication gene- rale en tenant compte des conditions person- nelles de ceux qu'il soigne, ainsi do reste que cela a tonjours été fait equitablement. Les personnes de la classe moins aisle seront traitees comme jadis et a des conditions con- formes a leurs moyens Pas plus qu'auparavant le recessiteuz et l'indigent ne feront vainemeet appel au devouement gratuit do medecin. Le corps medical, ne l'oubliez pas, est greve de nombreuses servitudes sociales. Dans les hopitaux, dispensaires, cliniques, mutualites, societies de bienfaisance, communautes, corpo- rations, orphelinats, ecoles, etc., il prodigue journellement ses soins a des milliers de personnes soit a titre purement gratuit, soit contre une retribution minime. Le passe a demontre, l'avenir confirmera qu'il ne se sous- trait jamais a cette charge. Mais il faut bien admettre que le medecin devant necessaire- ment s'adapter aux conditions économiques du milieu dans le seul il vit, il ne serait pas juste qu'il soit le seul a ne pas trouver de compensation aux frais plus considerables que lui impose la situation actuelle du pays. Le Conseil de l'Ordre dea medecins vous serait reconnsissant de bien vouloir donner a cette lettre la pnblieitl de votre estimable journal et vous prie d'agreer avec ses remer ciements anticipes l'assurance de sa parfaite consideration.
Le Conseil de l'Ordre.
Alexandrie, le 7 Janvier 1906.

div.head: OUR ROYAL VISITOR.
div.p: H. R. H. Prince Charles William of Sweden, after attending the review of the troops held at Abhassieh yesterday, returned to Shepheard's Hotel, where he is staying, and after a short interval went out on foot to view the town. In the morning, when the Prince was abont to leave for Abdeen Palace to pay his respects to the Khedive, he was greeted by a formi- dable array of tourists with kodaks, who took advantage of their position on Shepheard's terrace.
Prince William and his suite, accompanied by the Swedish Consul-General, Mr. C. Be- linfante-Ostberg, went out to the Pyramids on Sunday morning and took luncheon afterwards at Mena House Hotel.
His Royal Highness leaves for Luxor almost directly and will pass a fortnight at least on the Nile.

div.head: FRANCE AND EGYPT.
div.p: A Paris correspondent writesThe new penny postal tariff between England and Egypt has ''upset" the French postal administration. Advice from Port Said states that if France docs not adopt the peony postage In lieu of 2 1/2 d. between that country and France the French Port Said postal office will lose some 100,000 francs. per annum, besides many other advantages. The French postal system has yet much to learn.

div.head: CONSULAR APPOINTMENTS.
div.p: M. Abaza, Secretary to the Russian Consul General at Siam, has been appointed Russian Consol at Alexandria.
The Austro-Hungarian Government has appointed M. Goracuchi consul-general of the 1st class, ranking as diplomatic agent M. Maurice Campana has been appointed French Consul at Beyront
Mr. R.M. Graves has been appointed British Consular Assistant at Salonica.

div.head: EXCAVATIONS AT HELIOPOLIS
div.p: Professor Schiapparelli, director of the Egyptian Museum at Turin, intends to con duct some archaelogical excavations in the neighbourhood of Heliopolis. This eminent Italian Egyptologist arrived at Alexandria from Smyrna on Saturday last. He has bees engaged on some excavations in Asia Minor.

div.head: MENA HOUSE.
div.p: The large golf links at Mena House Hotel will reopen for the season on Monday, 15th inst. Day tickets, at 5 piastres each, must be obtained at the hotel office. India rubber soled -boss only may be worn.
There still be a small dance at Mena House Hotel on Wednesday. 17th inst., at 9.30 p m

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S. Creole Prince, with passengers and general cargo from Manchester, left Malta o- Monday, and it dot at Alexandria on the 12th inst,

div.head: Alexandria Harbour Port Extension Further description of work
div.p: In our issue of Wednesday last we gave an account of some of the great works now in progress for enlarging the accommodation of the harbour of Alexandria. In the following article we will conclode the review of the chief works.

At the end of the timber quays is the little harbour of Kamarieh. All the earth necessary for enlarging the quays, by the arsenal known officially as "J" and "K", are embarked at this spot The earth and stone come from the land between the Mex road and Lake Mareotis in front of the Alexandria slaughter-houses. When all this land is levelled, it will be one immense building estate, all round the native cemetery.
There is a credit of L.E. 180,000 for the timber quays.
Breakwater Extensions.

At the slaughter houses the jetty, which, has been begun since last year, will he extend- ed to a total length of 900 metres. Thence the breakwater will begin. It will be 41ft metres long and will extend in the direction of the smaller lighthouse on the large breakwater, which is also to be increased to the extent of 450 metres and will run in the same direction as it does now. Between these two new breakwater extensions the steamers entering and leaving the port will ran. Thus the harbour will bewail protected from the south-westerly and westerly gales.

In order to prevent the passage of the Boghaz pass being blocked by a wreck, a new pass is being made towards the large Mex lighthouse. A new lighthouse is to be built hereabouts, to indicate the direction of the new pass. This lighthouse will be pot in front of the small lighthouse. which is now used for indicating the Boghaz pass. Two powerful dredgers are now at work on the pass for which a credit of L.E. 100,000 has been greeted. The new pass will have a total width of 500 feet and a depth of 35 feet. The existing pass is only 300 feet wide and 30 feet deep. One of these passes will be reserved for ingoing, the other for outgoing ships.
Quarantine Jetty.

A credit of LE. 25,000 has been granted for the quarantine jetty, where cattle will be landed so as to be disembarked directly from the ships on to the quarantine park. This innovation will be a great protection to tbs country in regard to the importation of animals suffering from a contagious disease, and should be very effective in preventing the introduction of cattle plague and other bovine maladies into the country.
A very powerful dredger, which is capable of extracting 800 tons per hour, has been ordered from a Scotch firm and will cost £48,000. The coat includes also a tog and two barges.
A credit of L E 7,000 has been granted for enlarging the Arsenal quay on the west side of the floating dock and also for deepening the Arsenal basin.

The jetty protecting the Arsenal, which is 8 metres wide, will be enlarged to 100 metres in order to create four new berths Large ware- houses will be built there. The existing quay, known as "K," will be increased in rates so as to make room for new warehouses. A credit of LE 110,000 has been allotted for these mis- cellaneous works. The foundations for this extension have already been made to a great extent and only three metres remain to he filled up.
There are many other details which we could mention in regard to these works but the above general sketch should suffice to give a good idea of the vast works now in progress.

div.head: THE GRAND CADI.
div.p: H.M. the Sultan has conferred the ulema grade of "Istanboul Bayasi. I together with the Osmanieh (1st class), on the Grand Cadi of Egypt Sheikh Yehia wore his new uniform at the Khedive's reception yesterday at Abdeen Palace.

"Al Ah am" remarks : The Grand Cadi will tomorrow resume his duties in the Mehkemeh Sharieh, where he will find some changes have been made daring his absence by the Ministry of Justice. Wears awaiting with interest to know what steps this Ministry will take in the matter. Will the Ministry persist in adopting the new arrangements or leave the Mehkemeh to go on in the old fashion?

div.head: EGYPT AND BULGARIA.
div.p: The Bulgarian Government intends to esta- blish a commercial agency at Alexandria in view of the extension of Egyptian trade with Bulgaria
M. P. Dimitroff, Director of the Administra tive Section of the Bulgarian Foreign Office has been sent to Egypt to study the condition of a commercial arrangement between Egypt and Bulgaria

div.head: EGYPT AND ROUMANIA.
div.p: It is announced that a Roumanian consulate general will shortly be established in Egypt, and that M. Michel Pachario has been appoint -ed Diplomatic Agent at Cairo. He will take up his official dories on April 1.
The commercial relations between Egypt and Roumania are expected to rapidly develop with the establishment of the new Roumanian line ot steamers to Alexandria

div.head: ADVANCE SUDAN! PORT SUDAN LINE FIRST PASSENGER TRAIN TO ATRARA.
div.p: The line to Port Sudan will be completed in a few days, and traffic may be started on or about the 15th inst.

Commencing from 1st January, 1906, there is now a by weekly service of passenger trains, leaving Suakin for Atbara on Mondays and Fridays and arriving there on Tuesdays and Saturdays respectively. These trains start from Graham's Point station. The first pas- senger train from Suakin to Atbara left on the let inst. with a crowd of 1st, 2nd, and 3rd class passengers, a postal van being attached. The following among others left by the train : Miralai Persse Bey, commanding Ca- valry, E. A. ; Bimbashi Roberta, second in command, Artillery, B.A. ; Mr Peacocke, civil judge, Sudan Government; Rev. A. M. Thorn, Anglican chaplain, Sudan Mission, and Mr. Montagn, engineer, Sudan Government Rail- ways. A great number of officers and offi- cials were at Graham's Point station to see the train off) among then Miralai Macauley Rey, Kaimakam Longfield Bey, Kaimakam Sowerby Bey, Mr. Smail, etc.

By the train which arrived here from Khar- toum via Atbara on 27th ult. were Bimbashi Roberts, second in command of Artillery, B.A., and Mrs. Cominos (an English lady married to a Greek gentleman;, who can bout of being the first English lady to travel by train from Khartoum to Suakin.

Miralai Persse Bey, commanding Cavalry, E.A., and the Rev. A. M. Thorn, Auglican chaplain, arrived by the Khartoum train on 99th nit. Holy Communion wu celebrated by the Rev. Thorn on Sunday morning in the moudirieh chapel and in the evening (New Year's Eve) a service wu held, which was well attended.
New rear's Day.

To announce the New Year at Suakin a salute of 21 guns was fired at midnight from the new saluting fort erected at Graham's Point. Although New Year's Day was not observed u a general holiday, still the town was "en fate" and bedecked with flags, etc. The Khedivial mail steamers Mahallah and Missir dressed ship for the occasion. The Khedivial mail S.S. Mahallah arrived here from Son on the 31st unit, having on board Kaimakam Sadler Roy, Director of Sudan Customs, end a staff of English ins- pectors, eta, for the new Custom Homo at Port Sedan.
Mr. Smail, Loco Superintendent, Suakin District, also arrived by the Mahallah from Cairo, where be had been on a short leave of absence.
Mr. Peacocke, civil judge, Suakin Moodirieh, is transferred to Khartoum Moodirieh.
Mr. W. B. Echlin, late Suskin agent for Gellatly, Hankey, and Co, steamship agents, has been appointed an Inspector of Customs, Sudan Government.

div.head: A PRE-EMPTION CASE.
div.p: An interesting question of pre-emption has been decided by the Second Chamber of tile Mixed Court of Appeal in the cases of Ahmed Yehia and partners v. Hassan Pasha Mohsen, Cordalie, and partners. According to this judgment pre-emption cannot be derailed either by a property subject to hekr or on the profits of a property subject to hekr.

div.head: * THE GEOGRAPHY OF EGYPT AND THE SUDAN.
div.p: A new edition of Mr. H. W. Marden'a Geo- graphy of Egypt and the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan has been issued, and this most useful Work has been thoroughly revised and also considerably enlarged. This little text book was in fact unique in its way, for we know of no other work dealing with the geography of Egypt and the Sudan in such a handy and ractical way. The writer has hid the assis- tance of the most eminent authorities in Egypt in order to obtain end control his formation, and the result is that the book is as much a work of reference for the general reader in Egypt u it is a text hook for the pupil in Egyptian Schools.
*A Geography of Egypt and the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan. By; H.W Mardon,Tewfieh Training College, Caire London Blackie and son.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Sir Vincent Corbett will leave Cairo for the Sudan most probably on the 17th inst The Financial Adviser intends to be at Suakin for the inauguration of the Nile-Red Sea line on the 27th inst.
Ahmed Bey Mustepha.Sub-Moudir of Minieh, has resigned his position to enter the Native Bar.
H.H. the Khedive granted an audience yesterday morning to Nadjeeb Bay El Bustani, son of the late Butros El Bustani, the author of the Arabic Encyclopedia of the Lebanon
We regret to learn that Mr. J. Clarke-Shaw, of the Government School at Ru el-Tin, has been rather seriously indisposed. He has now, however, taken a torn for the better.

We note that Mr. C. M. Crookshank, of Sainthill Park, Grinstead, who is the youngest brother of Crookshank Pacha, is the Conservative candidate for the But Grinstead division, contesting the constituency with Mr. C. H. Corbett (L). Mr. Crookshank is a staunch supporter of Mr. Belfoir, and hopes he may in tune go u 1st u the proposals of Mr. Chamberlain. Both candidates have taken an active part in local work, and served on several governing bodies. Mr. Corbett is a solicitor by profession. Mr. Crookshank has now given up actual work, except that of a political nature. He has often been nailed in to advise the Board of Agriculture, end was for a while Professor of Bacteriology at King's Collage. Having travelled a good deal in the Colonies, Mr. Crookshank is intimately acquainted with the needs of our kindred across the seas.

We cull the following from an American contemporary :-Miss M. C. Markham,'Cornell '93, who has been visiting her sister, Mrs. H. F. Button at Forest Home, has left for New York City, whence she will sail for Cairo, Egypt, to accept a permanent position. Miss Markham, who upon leaving Cornell took a course in Bellevue Medical School, has been very successful in her profession, having been in charge at Porto Rico doling the Spaniah War end later wu one of three American nurses chosen by the first Panama Commission to take charge of the American Hospital at the Canal Zone She resigned her position there to accept this better opening in Egypt, and her many friends here will hope to hear of her continued success.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY,
div.p: FOOTBALL
ST. ANDREW v. H. Co. R. DUBLIN FUS.

The above teams met on Saturday last on the ground of the former et Moharrem Bey, when a most enjoyable game was played. The teams were of very equal strength, and both in torn tested the opposing defence. The Saints almost got through on two occassions in the first half, the ball going past by inches. The Dubs retaliated in spirited fashion but could not find an opening. Both halves were very evenly contested and the game ended in a goalless drew, s result thoroughly representative of the run of the play. The following were the teams:
H. Co. Dubs. Doyle, Moran, Frost, Taylor, Sallinger, McGrave, Wilkie, Pendir, McGuire, Walsh, Hearns.
Saint Andrew. — Webb, Hopkins, Rofe, Metzga, Cowie, Keill, Constantinidis, Lark, Curtis, Jones, Tulloch.

div.p:
Built In 1904. Modern House. Splendid situation. Eectric Light
Lift, Pension P.T. 50. Arrangements for families.
Rooms and Breakfast P.T. 25.— Meals a la Cart

ORCHESTRA PLAYS 6 TO 11.30 P.M

div.head: THE MOROCCO QUESTION. GERMANY AND THE POWERS. ISSUE OF GERMAN WHITE BOOK.

div.p: The Press asks whether, in view of the apparent intention of most of the Powers to support France at the Morocco Conference, Germany is prepared to alienate the opinion of the world.:
It is believed that Germany has been sound ing the Powers'on the subject of an interna tional police in Morocco. (Reuter)

The German White Book concerning Mo- rocco has been issued. It bears. evidence of having been carefully compiled, rather for the purpose of establishing Germany's standpoint than as a retort to the Yellow Book. It shows that the Sultan emphatically assured the German representative that France was claim- ing to be the mandatory of Europe, and adduces various facts tending to prove the contention that French reform schemes implied complete French control in Morocco. Prinoe von Billow maintains that, in de- manding the Conference, Germany is defending the interests of all Powers. (Reuter)
The Emperor is keeping his room owing to a chill (Havas)
Meetings in favour of friendly relations with Great Britain continue. (Reuter)
M. Witte has declared in an interview that he is convinced that Russia will emerge reju- venation from the present crisis, of which reports nave been exaggerated. (Reuter)

M. Kokovzoft, ex-Minister of Russian Fi- nance, who has been interviewed here, said that the crisis had never reached a point sufficiently grave to compromise the credit of the country. The extraordinary expense of 49f),000,000 roubles, for the re-patriation of troops and the payment to be made to Japan will be covered by an exterior loan. The recent repressive measures have brought Anarchists to their senses. Public peace is henceforth secure. (Reuter)
A force sent to Windau has arrested the local Socialist committee. Three ringleaders were killed while attempting to escape. (R.)
The Turkish troops' in the Yemen have been checked. They were compelled to re- treat to Omran, where they await 8,COO re- inforcements. (Reuter)
The King signed the decree for the dissola- tion of Parliament This afternoon. (Reuter)
The Left will decide to oppose the Candida- tore of M. Sarrien to that of M. Doomer for the presidency of the Chamber. (Havas)
At the triennal elections for the Senate M. Juares and his Socialist colleagues were badly beaten. (Reuter)
Count Goluchowski is reported to have the intention to resign. The Hungarians are insisting on his removal. (Havas)

The inquest regarding the accident at the Charing Cross station has returned a verdict of "Accidental death." The railway is declared to be without blame. Sir Benjamin Baker stated that a flaw in a tie-rod, due to a bad weld, was the cause of the disaster. He advised the removal of the remainder of the old roof, and the erection of a new One. (R.)

div.head: PHARAOH'S TREASURY.
div.p: The most interesting route from or to Egypt is by way of Petra, and the present volume contains an excellent account of this somewhat difficult trip. It is a two-volume work bearing the title 'The Jordan Valley and Petra,' by Dr William Libbey, Professor of Physical Geography in Princeton University, and Dr. Franklin E Hoskins of the Syria Mission at Bayront. Their trip, which was made less diffi- cult than such trips usually are by a letter from the Waly of Damascus to the Mutaserrif of Kerak, asking him to take them down to Petra and bring them back again, was from Joppa by sea to Sidon and eastward to Mount Lebanon, then south to the Sea of Galilee, along the eastern side of the Jordan Valley to Petra, the valley of Moses, then back to the Dead Sea, and west of it to Jerusalem and Joppa. Such a journey leads one "into regions of country and of history that are far from the beaten line of the ordinary traveller.' The book, which contains a uniqne aeries of photographs, gives a vivid and picturesque account of the present condition of the country through which the children of Islam passed from their bondage in Egypt to the Promised Land. From much material in the volumes that is profitable and interesting, we shall confine ourselves to the visit to Petra.

The authors spent five days in the city of Petra, 'a rose-red city half as old as Time,' where only twenty-five Europeans have entered during a hundred years, and nearly all of whom entered by stealth, and more than half were driven-out after a harried glance at the won dare and mysteries of the place. Not more than three or four were allowed to spend a night within the mins, hot our two authors remained five days and floated the American flag un- molested within the ancient city. The entrance to this 'strangest city on our planet,' and the first view of 'Pharaoh's Treasury', are described aa follows:

'Seen at morning, midday, or at midnight, the Sik, this matchless entrance to a hidden city, is unquestionably one of the great, glories of ancient Petra. We wandered on, amazed, enchanted, and delighted, not wishing for, no' excepting anything that could be finer than this, when a look ahead warned us that we were approaching some monument worth atten tion, and suddenly we stepped oat of the narrow gorge into the sunlight again. Them in front of us, carved in the face of the cliff, half-revealed, half-concealed, in the growing shadows, was one of the largest, most perfect. and most beantiful mono meets of antiquity,— Pharaoh's Treasury!'
The volumes are exceedingly well illustrated, and contain scientific data that are not generally accessible elsewhere.
The Jordan Valley and Potra. by William Libbery and Franklin E. Hoskins. In two volumes. Illustrated. New York G.P. Putnam's Sons

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITORS
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish. In a spirit of fair play to all, to permit — within certain necceesary limits— free discussion.

div.head: FINANCIAL ADVISER'S NOTE. THE SPECULATION BOGEY. e
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette. „

Sir,—Both the critics of the Financial Ad- viser's "note of warning," who style themselves , "A Sincere Admirer of the British Administra tion in Egypt" and "Anglo-Egyptian," are evidently persons engaged in business in this country and are consequently unable to grasp "the highest motives of statesmanship," which "A Sincere Admirer" acknowledges has actuat- ed Lord Cromer and Sir Vincent Corbett to t utter these "ex-cathedra" notes of warning, In the first place, those critics appear to pre- sume that one of the chief "raisons d'etre" of British officialdom in Egypt should be the encouragement of capitalists. Up to a certain point British capital is i necessary for Egypt, but too great an influx would be a danger to the country, for it would lead to the formation of a very small number of British—or Anglo- Jewish, to speak more correctly—capitalists obtaining soon a gigantic interest in Egypt, as to be a menace to its independent govern ment. There is no immediate danger as long as Lord Cromer stays at the helm, for he is strong enough to cope with this danger, but statesmen mast look to the future, and I ven- ture to state that it is these most dangerous , symptoms of the development of the power of a very few European capitalists in Egypt which Lord Cromer and Sir Vincent Corbett have before them, when uttering that class of state- ments to which some of your reader have taken such exception. Whether Sir Vincent Corbett ' is or is not correct in the statements in his Budget Note iB a problem the discussion of which is not to the point. Possibly the writer of the first letter on this subjeot in his able criticism of the Financial Adviser'a statements may be perfectly right in showing that they are not justified by the facts. But the vital question does not concern snob points as the maximum value of building sites, etc. The real problem is whether the growth of the influence of any one capitalist or group of capitalists is not likely to develop into a serious menace to the good government of Egypt; and are not the British administrators here justified in warding off that danger by all the means that lie in their power? For my part i think there is ample justification, and the more the power of great capitalists is curbed, the better it will be for the country to be free from those dangerous extraneous influences which have wrought each have in South Africa.
—Truly yours, A Liberal Imperialist.
Cairo, January 8.

div.head: DISCONTENTED EGYPTIANS. '
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,—Your correspondent 'Observer," in his letter of the 29th ult., referring to mine of the 27th idem, accuses me of little know- ledge of Egypt, and then, while admitting the discontent among the natives, states that so long as the British forces are close at hand we need have little fear of any trouble. Let me inform your correspondent that though I have been a resident in this country for many years, I am open to receive additions to my knowledge of Egypt from him or from any other lady or gentleman who may be charitably disposed to impart them. "Obser- ver," however, is altogether wrong in believing that any British Government—even a Tory one —would be disposed to employ the British forces—naval or military—to do in this country the work of Bashi-Bazuoks in Turkey or of Cossacks in Russia.

The fact remains that though the discontent is admitted by all your correspondents, few suggest remedies. From all sides we hear of the increased cost of living. Lately I have seen in your paper, the Alexandria Medical Council have decided to raise doctors fees. What isbeing done for the poor, the fellaheen and the labouring classes, on whom the increased cost cf living mast press even more heavily I The only way to banish all feelings of discontent is to make their lot happier than it is at present. I suggested some reforms that might be carried oat and the adoption of which would make natives understand they were infinitely better off under a British protectorate than they could ever hope to be under the role of Sulton Abdel Hamid.
- Yours truly, J. Amigo.
Port Said, January 6.

div.head: MEAT IN ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,—During a recent visit to Cairo I re- marked the superior quality of the meat there as compared with that to be found in Alexandria. It was explained to me that the reason for this was that, whereas, in Alex- andria, cattle are taxed according to their weight, in Cairo, the tax is so much a head, consequently, all the beat cattle go to Cairo and the lean ones, which would not bear a poll tax, remain here. This explanation is a plausible one. Be this as it may, it is evident that there must be a reason for the pre- sence in the "paro quarantenaire" here of so many cattle in such a poor miserable condition that they excite one's pity. For them, the but other's knife mast be a happy release ; but I dare say that many do not trouble him.

As the guardians of the public health, might one venture to ask our City Fathers to enquire into the matter. A medical friend, if mine assured me that the prevalence of in this country was, in a great mea- sure, due to the bad quality of the meat which the Authorities allowed to be imported, and he advised me to eat as little of it as possi- ble.
—Yours truly, ENQUIRER.
Alexandria, 8 January.

div.head: SCOTS WHA HAH.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,—We, the undersigned Hielanders, on arrival in this benighted country, were devoyed by promises of the great social advantages accruing from membership of the A L M.D.8., etc., into joining the society at the considerable figure of ten saxpences. The above mentioned advantages included two to seven entertainments per month, with a dance to wind op the season with. Wo beg to state that half the social season of Alexandria has slipped by and the only thing in the way of entertainment offered us is a lecture on "The Desert of Sinai" Now, although (this was an excellent lecture, we prefer the one, also "On the Desert of Sinai" by Moses, as given in the Book of Exodus, although without the limelight accompaniment.

This is not written in any carping Spirit but last to wake up the committee of the above alphabetically designated orgnisation to the necessity of giving us, and of course the other members, a ran for our money. When you come to think of the number of plates of porridge represented by ten saxpences and the well-known objection our countrymen have to parting with the same, yon will probably sympathise with us, and print the above.
Yours, etc,
W. Macqregor.
T. McTavish.
Alexandria, 8th January.

div.head: IN HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S CONSULAR COURT AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: REGISTRATION.
NOTICE is hereby given that all British subjects residing within the district of this consulate are bound to register themselves during the month of January.

All persons neglecting so to register them- selves are liable to a fine of £5 or to be imprisoned for not more than one month. The consulate will be open daily from 10 a.m. till noon for this delivery of registration certificates.
27055-6-5 BY ORDER.

div.head: Navy Contracts.
div.p: PORT SAID and SUEZ.

TENDERS are hereby invited for new Contracts for the supply of Fresh Beef, Mutton, Vegetables, Soft Bread, and Water to His Majesty's Ships at Port Said and Suez for twelve months from 1st April 1906.
Each article should be tendered for separate- ly, bat the tenders for all the articles offered by any particular firm most be placed on the same form.

Prices should be quoted in English currency. Forms of Application can be obtained from the Navy Agent, British Consulate, Port Said, to wham tenders should be sent in duplicate, in sealed envelope, in time to be received not later than the 31st January 1906.
The Admiralty reserve the right of rejecting all or any tenders, and of accepting any portion of a tender.
(signed) D. A. CAMERON, Navy Agent.
British Consulate, Port Said, 6th January 1906.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: It is notified for information that the Nazi and Offices of the Department of Stores at Assouan are situated at Gezira Nile Siding, where all stores for the Sudan are transferred from rail to boat, and all stores from Sudan to Egypt are transferred from boat to rail. The Department of Stores has neither office nor staff at Shellal nor at Assouan Station, nor at North End Station, and only takes over packages at Gezira Nile Siding.
All packages forwarded through the stores Officer, Assouan, should therefore be addressed "Gezira Nile Siding" or they will not be taken over by the Department of Stores.

div.head: WANTED.
div.p: Manager required by an English Land Company established in Egypt. Applicants must have a thorough knowledge of Egypt, speak English and Arabic, and be competent judge of land. Salary £600 to £700 per annum. Applications to be addres- sed to L.H.T., P.0, Box 161, Cairo.

div.head: THE SUEZ CANAL. SHIPOWNERS AND THE RATES.
div.p: In a recent issue we published the text of the letter, which Lord Lansdowne. before leav- ing the Foreign Office, caused to he addressed to the Chamber of Shipping on the future administration of the Suez Canal. The "Shipping Gazette" voices the British shipping interests in its protest against Lord Lansdowne's state- ments and thus criticises .the policy which Lord Lansdowne foreshadows

Pat in a few words, it is a point-blank re- fusal to assist them in the slightest degree, although the British Government owns nearly half the shares in the Suez Canal Company, end although British shipping provides some-! thing like three-fourths of the revenge of the Canal. The considerations which have led the late Foreign Secretary to this decision can only be guessed at, but shipowners will, we are afraid, be driven to the conclusion that their interests have been deliberately sacrificed to the entente on the one hand, and to the po- verty of the Chancellor of the Exchequer on the other. They will also, we fear, form the inevitable opinion that their claims have not been very cordially backed by the Board of Trade, which in this matter has .mainly acted as a sort of bottle-Bolder.

To come to the details of Lord Lansdowne's letter, we find it first of all laying stress on the fact that an arrangement in respect of covered- in spaces was arrived at in November, 1904. between the Board of Trade and the Suez Canal Company, and that in the opinion of the Board of Trade it provided .for an Equitable deduc- tion. Bat we are not aware that the Board of Trade is specially qualified,to judge on such a point, and in the opinion of fhipowners the effort made by Whitehall gardens to settle this question was as unsatisfactory as it was un- solicited.' Then, again, Lord Lansdowne is apparently impressed with the circumstance that Suez Canal tonnage dues were settled by an International Commission in 1873, and he assumes, therefore, that, with sundry modifica- tions made from time to time since then, they most be perfect in their impartiality and up- to dateness. Nothing is farther from the fact. The loose administration of its tonnage rules by the Suez Canal Company is a most serious grievance, if on'y because it tends to make economical trading impossible in many cases, gives preference to one class of ship over another, and tends generally to penalise pro- gress in ship construction. If an International Commission dealt with this subject in 1878, it seems just a possibility that thirty-two years later it would be a useful proceeding to appoint another body of the same kind. But Lord Lansdowne's letter forbids any expectation in that direction.

As regards the complaint that the Suez Canal Company have broken the Agreement of 1888, which provided for the consistent re- daction of canal dues, Lord Lansdowne makes two points. He says, in the first place, that the then Government took no part in bringing it about. In the second place, he accepts the view that it was a mere programme It is quite true, no doubt, that after vainly trying to settle by agreement with M; de Lesseps the questions which bad arisen, the Government of that day wanted shipowners to deal direct with the great engineer, and that they did so. But what was the nature of the arrangement made in the board-room of the P. and 0. Company between the shipowners and M. Charles de Lesseps on behalf of his father 1 Sir Thomas Sutherland, in his useful record of the events of that period, heads his account of the various stages as folloWs:— "Agreement Signed," "Nature of Agreement," "Agreement accepted by the Country." Mr. Westray, too, who acted as secretary to the shipowners, sent a copy of it Off post haste to Lord Granville, with a covering letter in which he said: " I have the honour to forward a copy of an agreement, C, and C" We also have Sir Thomas Sutherland, stating in the "P. and O. Pocket Book" for 1888-9: "It is also satisfactory at once to " state that, though by no means agreeable to " shareholders of the Canal, the agreement was " accepted, mid has been loyally carried out by " the company. " We wonder whether Lorn Lansdowne was furbished with a copy of this particular article, because it should have con- vinced him that for the Government to say that it took no part in the settlement is very mean. It mights also have induced him to hesitate before believing that the solem meeting in the board room of the P. and 0 Company in 1883 was really intended to be faroical.

Lord Lansdowne has, we fear, given bat a superficial examination ti this subject. other wise he would not excite ridicule by assumin that when, in 1900, the London Committee acquiesced in the breaking cf the Agreemen- of 1883. they acted as 'representatives of the original parties to the understanding." By the year 1900 the London Committee had dev* loped for the most part into a self-appointed clique. It was not, indeed, until 1904 that the shipowners of the country generally knew that their birthright had been abandoned, and without even the compensation of the custo- mary mess of potage. Well may Lord Lans downe now pay that "the body known as the " London Committee is not as cloesly in " touch as might be desirable with the varions " branches of the shipping trade " We wish be had a'en his way to go further, and t« declare that, in the interests of British Ship owners in general, the present misrepresen- tation of their interests on the Suez Canal board mu-1cense. That, however, is bound to come in time, despite what we must call tin timidity of Lord Lansdowne. For the moment it is true. Prince d'Arenberg and his satellites are triumphant, but the accession of a new Government to office may mean new and more enlightened views on this subject. Our sincere regret is that the Foreign Minister of a Government which professed to make British trade its first consideration should have beer afraid to revise the charge at the main toll gate of the Empire's shipping and should have given countenance to the theory that m Agreement may be broken if it only pays to do so.

div.head: FESTIVITIES AT BOULAC. EGYPTIAN RAILWAY INSTITUTE.
div.p: The committee of the above institute held their first meeting of, the year in a rather auspicious manner. They have been going on for several years now, with-nothing but dry committee work, week zfter week. Recognising that all work and no play "makes Jack a dull bey," they tamed from work to refreshment on Thursday evening last. The meeting had been called earlier than usual and after disposing of the usual routine of business connected with the -institution, the committee adjourned to another room to sit down to dinner. The manager who purveyed had the tables laid out wi£h ail that the most fastidious could desire, and it goes without saying that all the good things pat forward were done ample justice to. Dinner, being over,, glasses were charged. Mr. Crossley proposed the health of the pre- sident, Mr. Trevithick, and in doing so remark- ed that much of the success during the past year had been in a great measure doe to the president, who, he said, was always with the committee when they proposed anything for the benefit of the members.

Mr. G. Walker, the chairman, replied on behalf of Mr. Trevithick, who was unavoidably absent. Mr. Walker gave "The Visitors," to which Mr. J. A. Bell responded. He said it had given him great pleasure to assist at the festi- vities daring -New Year's Day.

Rev. Mr. Borns,Who is a privileged member, asked Mr. Ison to rise with him and drink the health of the committed, and in doing so remarked that it was a pleasure to him to sit amongst the gentlemen who governed the insti- tution; He also stated that when the general meeting came round, if the members would be advised, they would return the same men, and also when his time came to retire, that if the members desired he would be only too pleased to sit for another term, finally remarking "Oh ! Committee, oh! Committee live for ever" (applause). Mr. Walker, in replying, said it was a pleasure to him to be chairman of such a committee, every individual member of which was a worker. Mr. Esau proposed the ladies, and coupled the toast with the name of Mr. Ison. Mr. Ison, replying, said that although not a ladies' man, he was proud of the honour to reply to such a toast. He hoped that if they had a similar function, and that at an early period, they would not omit to invite the ladies.

The Rev. Borns gave '"The Old Folks at Home," remarking that while we were enjoying ourselves in a foreign lard we should not forget those who remained at home. Mr. Trotter briefly but feelingly replied. T. Eff. Badir gave "The Treasurer." Mr Eraux suitably replied. Mr. Eraux gave "The Secretary" and Gabriel Eff Raphael responded. Mr. Bell gave "The Children" and Mr. Crossley replied. Mr. Walker proposed the health cf Mr. Savino, who he said was one of the oldest members of the committee. Mr. Savino briefly replied through Mr. Otto. Mr. Ison gave "The Press," to which Mr. John Cooper responded. Gabriel Eff. Raphael proposed the health of Mr. Crossley, who replied in a happy and humorous manner. Mr. Trotter gave "The Chairman," who, he said,Vet an example to the committee, by the way in which he worked for the benefit of every member. The company sang "He's a jolly good Fellow," after which Mr. Walker briefly replied thanking the mem- bers for the support given him since he became chairman. The singing of "Auld Lang Syne" brought a very enjoyable and harmonious, evening to a close.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN 1905.
div.p: Discussing the cotton trade in 1905, the Manchester Guardian" states that Egyptian cotton, like American, has tended upward daring the year, and the movement has not be'n merely "sympathetic," for the spinners' demand has coincided roughly with the advance in price. Folly good fair was 7 and 1/15d. on January 3, and on February 1 it touched 6 and 9/15d., the lowest point of the year. There have been fluctuations, of coarse, but a fairly steady rise brought it to 8 and 7/15d. on November 6, and though this price has hardly been maintained there has teen no serious reaction. According to official returns the acreage under cotton in Upper Egypt this season is 310,699 feddans (a feddan equals 3-25 acres) against. 243,409 feddans last season, and in Lower Egypt 1,255,644 feddans against 1,193,298 feddans. The total acreage is therefore 1,566,343 fed- lans against 1,456,707 feddans last season, and the November estimate of the Alexandria General Produce Association indicated a crop of 6,750,000 cantars. Subsequent reports have been fairly favourable, but at a meeting of the Produce Association early in December it was decided that this estimate of 6,750,000 cantars should be considered as a maximum. The demand for Egyptian cotton continues to be a very strong one, and the position Bolton spinners indicates that it will be maintained. The total crop of 6,351 879 cantars for the easrn 1904 5 against 6,508,947 cantars for I9f 3-4 is hardly a sufficiency for the growing uesds cf the world Up to December 20 the receipts were 3,360,455 cantars, against 3,188,145 car tars in 1904 and 3,903,127 can- tars in 1903.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN SUDAN. EDUCATIONAL SYSTEM.
div.p: Not the least of the reforms which have been introduced into the Sudan since the overthrow of the Khalifa must be accounted the organisation of the bases of an educational system, modelled in accordanoe with the most modern ideas along lines adapted to the needs of the country. At the present stage of deve lopment the schools directly under the central authority of the Education Department, which is represented by an Education Office at Khartoum, falls under five heads: (1) elemen- tary vernacular schools, (2) higher elementary schools, (3) instructional workshops, (4) higher schools, (5) training colleges.
Elementary Vernacular Teaching.

Naturally the majority of the schools are comprised in the first of theses classes, The ordinary elementary vernacular course consists of the simplest principles of religion, reading, writing, and the elements of arithmetic, and a boy of average ability, entering the school when about seven years of age, should work through the coarse in three years. At some of the elementary vernacular schools advanced classes have lately been formed to train in land measurement boys who wish to enter the Survey Department. Until recently a school was worked in connection with the Steamers and Boats Department, apprentices spending alternate days in the workshops of the depart- ment and in the school. This school has now been merged in the Government Elementary Vernacular School at Khartoum, bat the system of alternate teaching in school and workshop is being maintained. According to the returns for the current school year, 1905-6, there are alto- gether thirteen elementary vernacular schools controlled or inspected by theSudan Education Department. Of these there are two in the Khartoum Province, at Khartoum and Omdur- man ; one in the Suakin Province, at Saakin ; four in the Berber Province, at Berber, El-' Damer, Shendi, and Metemma; two in the Blue Nile Province, at Ruffa'a and Wad-Medani; two in the Kassala Province, at Kassala and Gadarif; and one apiece in the Dongola and White Nile Provinces, at Dongola and Geteina respectively. The total number of pupils is returned as 783, of whom 684 are classed as "natives," mainly Arabs,and 69 as Egyptians. The largest elementary vernacular sohool is that at Omduran, with 130 pupils, and the smallest that at Metemma, with 21 pupils.
Higher Grade Schools.

A hoy who has passed satisfactorily through the elementary vernacular course will know enough to enter one of the higher grade schools. His choice of a school will depend on the career it is proposed he should follow, since the higher grade coarses have been carefully plan- ned so as to qualify every boy passing through them to occupy some position of public utility. In the schools classed as "Higher Elementary," instruction is given in classical Arabic, religion, the elements of the English language, arith- metic, geography, geometry, drawing, land- measurement, drill, and gymnastics. The curriculnm is spread over at least four years, and on its successful completion a boy will he , ready either to eater the higher school or to fill subordinate posts in various branches of the public service, while it is hoped that those whose circumstances place them above the need of earning their own livelihood will learn enough to lead them in after life to take an intelligent view of the responsibilities as well as the privileges of their position. At present only four Higher Elementary Schools, with 511 pupils, are controlled or inspected by the Education Department That at Khartoum forms part of the Gordon College and has 182 pupils, cf whom 116 are "natives" (27 Arabs and 41 Blacks) and 65 Egyptians. The others are at Omdurman (166 pupils), Suakin (100 pupils), and Haifa (63 pupils).
Technical Instruction.

What are called Instructional Workshops form another class of higher-grade schools. At present there is in existence only one solitary representative of this type of school—the Instructional Workshop, founded by Sir Wil- liam Mather in the Gordon College. It has been decided, however, to open shortly schools of a similar character in Omdurman and Kassala, while reference has already been made to the technical instruction imparted in connection with the Elementary Vernacular School at Khartoum. Id the Mather Workshops —where considerable extensions are contem- plated — practical instruction is givenL in carpentry, smith's work, and the fitting and running of machinery ) the elements of arith- metic and drawing are also taught, and all the boys are obliged to drill. There are 92 pupils on the register, of whom 12 are Egyp- tians, 16 Arabs, 19 Blacks, and 8 Berberine, a large number being designated "mixed natives."
Professional Training.

Of the Higher Schools there is also at present only one representative, and this, too, is in connection with the Gordon College. It is designed for students who have satisfactorily completed the courses in the Higher Elementary Schools, who are preparing to become assistant engineers, overseers, or surveyors. As yet it can boast of only 15 pupils. More popular is the Training College which has been started at Khartoum, in connection with the Gordon College, for the purpose of enabling students to qualify for responsible positions in the Departments t.f Education and Justice (Mohamedan Courts). This has 103 Dames enrolled on its books this year, all described 1 as natives and 97 of them Arabs. The Course.

is an advanced one intended for students between the ages of 17 and 24, and as now arranged covers five years. It is noteworthy that all instruction is in the vernacular language. Another Training'College with a two years' course has been founded at Omdurman for the purpose of training teachers for the Elementary Vernacular Schools. This has 27 pupils (24 Arabs), but a third Training College under the Education Department, established at Suakin, is credited with only a couple of students, both Arabs.
Importance of Gordon College.

The foregoing particulars may perhaps suggest a question whether the educational system which is being established in the Sudan is not a little too much of a machine for turn- ing oat Government officials, though the need for reliable subordinate native agents is ad- mittedly great Doubtless, if there is any such tendency it will be corrected as time goes on. It is apparent how important a part the Gordon College is playing in promoting higher educa- tion in the Sudan. Of the nine schools and colleges controlled or inspected by the Edu- cation Department, other than Elementary Vernacular Schools, the Gordon College com- prises four, and out of 750 pupils it claims 892. Including the Elementary Vernacular Schools the Department has under it 22 schools of all classes, situated in 16 towns scattered over eight of the dozen provinces in the Anglo- Egyptian Sudan. There is thus ample room for the extension of the good work begun daring the last few years. The total number ~of pupils is 1,683, of whom 1,419 are Moslems and 107 Christians. Only one-seventh of the total (220) are Egyptians, while of 1,237 as nearly as possible one half (614) are Arabs, 134 being Blacks, 133 Berberine, and 346 mixed natives"; 86 are returned as neither Egyptian nor native.

div.head: "ORIENT AND OCCIDENT."
div.p: This excellent moral and religions magazine has entered on its second year of existence and we congratulate the editors, the Rev. W. H T. Gardner and the Rev. D. M. Thorn ton, on the success of their efforts. For those of our readers who are not yet acquainted with this interesting Cairo publication, we extract the following passage from the latest issne, showing the aims of oar contem- porary, which is published in Arabic as well as in English

" If in our first number last year we appealed to be received as brothers, we wish to take oar stand this year on this as a fact accomplished. " Brotherhood " in spite of every ..factor of reparation, whether of Class, Country, or Creed—this is the fact upon which we take oar stand this year. We do not believe this spirit to be contradictory to the spirit of Egyp- tian patriotism and national feeling. On the contrary it is our intention to encourage and foster all true patriotic feeling in the future as we have in the past, for we are sure that the best friends of a country are those who are seeking ti strengthen its spirit of esprit de corps. We have reasons for believing that it is recognized in Egypt that we desire to foster and encourage Egyptian initiative, and to hear and give expression to the Egyptian point of view, if only from the fact that free discussion gees on in our premises, and that young Egyptians, irrespective of creed, come to us from time to time to seek advice or ask for facilities in their plans for mutual help and independent action. These ideas of Uni- versal Brotherhood and National Spirit we shall therefore emphasize this year, and we shall seek to discover the principles by which they can each be developed and yet combined. "We hope to give a dear note on some of the problems which confront Egypt to-day, and in doing so we invite discussion and the free expression of opinion, provided it be temperate and fair. Farther, in doing so we desire to stimulate, in Egyptians themselves of the younger generation, the spirit of accurate thinking, of initiative in action, and of efficiency in organization, so as to be able to work out their own destiny in days to come upon Eastern lines."

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE THEATRE ALHAMBRA
div.p: La trope française d'opérettes, Crépy- Simon, a donné hier à l'Alhambra sa première représentation déü "Travaux d'Hercule", opéra- bouffe parodie de MM. Caillavet et de Fiers, musique de Terrasse.

C'est bien, comme livret,, une des pièces les plus surprenantes du répertoire nouveau : du commencement à la fin ce n'est qu'un feu rou- lant de bons mets et d'allusions bouffonnes, qui réjonissent l'esprit et provoquent des accès de gaieté ininterrompus. En apparence le sujet ressemble assez à celui de "la Belle Hélène-,' mais là parodie des héros. mythologiques dans les Travaux d'Hercule''sert décadré à , u e étude psychologique intéressante : ce héros de contrebande qui dort et mange jour et unit et. dont tonte la renommée repose sur une erreur populaire qui consiste à lui attribuer les ex ploits de son rival constitne nue leçon dé choses satirique des pins réussies.

Que dire des scènes diverses sinon que la plupart d'entre elles sont des trouvailles. Quant b la musique elle s'adapte parfaite- ment an sujet : elle centient des passages et surtout certains chœurs ravissants.

Après ce court aperçu de l'opéra lui-même, il nous reste à parler de l'exécution : celle-ci fait le pins grand honéeor à la troupe de M.M. Crépy et Simon. L'ensemble a été parfait; mais, comme il serait trop long de nous arrêter k chaque acteur on actrice, nous nous bornerons à dire un mot des râles principaox ;

M. de La Freydière a fait une entrée sensa- tionnelle dans son costume d'Hercule qui loi seyait à merveille : sa corpulence, sa taille, sa connaissanoe du râle le désignaient à cette tâche écrasante qu'il a su mener jusqu'ac bout avec une sûreté admirable. M. Coutelier que nous connaissions déjà comme un excel- lent acteur a été tout à fait brillant dans le tôle d'Augias. Très bien également M. Simon en Palémon et M. La Bany en Orphée. M. Ballin en Xanthias a été le type du parfait tapeur.
De Mlle Ch'antenay nous dirons seulement qu'elle a obtenu eon succès habituel dans son râle d'Omphale ainsi que Mite Nolba dans celui d'amazone.

Bref avec "Les Travaux d'Hercule'' la tronpe française d'opérette a donné la mesure de ce quelle pouvait faire, d'autant plus que cet opéra a du être en quelques jours étudié et monté de toutes pièces.
On donne œ soir "Les Dragons de Villars."

div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALES
L'ELECTION DBS CONSEILLERS EXPORTATEURS
div.p: Ce n'est pas sans une certaine satisfaction, mêlée de surprise, que nous avons appris la résolution do Président de la Commission Mu- nicipale, S. E. le Gouverneur d'Alexandrie, d'obliger enfin les exportateurs de notre ville k Be- conformer à la loi pour leurs prochaines élections.

On sait, en effet, que nos conseillers expor- tateurs sont élus depuis longtemps d'une façon tout à fait irrégulière, sans contrôle et en comité secret Noou avons toujours signalé cet abus, mais sans résultat L'année dernière, è la suite de nos articles, cette élection fit l'objet d'une protestation presque unanime, mais le comité des exportateurs fit la Bourde oreille. C'est sans doute pour éviter le retour de pareils incidents que le Gouverneur d'Alexandrie s'est résolu a mettre un terme à cette irrégularité.
Quel que, soit le mobile qui l'ait déterminé, nous enregistrons avec plaisir le but atteint.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: La cote en général fléchit, pendant que quel- ques valeurs continuent à hausser. Mais les transactions demeurent clairseméea sur toute la ligne. Cet état du marché provient de l'in- certitude qui règne dans le domaine politique. Parmi les valeurs qui haussent vient en premier lieu l'Anglo-American Nile, dont le cours atteint 5 7/8, puis les Egyptian Hotels qui montent d'un coup de 3 3/4 à 3 15/16 les New Egyptian de 28/9 à 29/3, L Daira' de 17 9/16 à 17 5/8 et le Comptoir de 4 7/16 k 4 U

Mais un grand nombre d'autres titres ac- cusent une baisse plus ou moins sensible. La National Bank tombe à 25 13/16, l'action Crédit Foncier à 803, l'Obligation à 334, la Banque d'Athènes à 132, l'Investment à 1 3/32, les Estâtes kl 9/16, la Filature à 13/16, la Sait and Soda 20/3, la Nungovioh à H 5/8, lee Upper Egypt Hotels à 5 8/16 et la Bras- serie des Pyramides à 110.
C'est le bruit d'un faible dividende qui a déterminé la baisse de l'Investment.
Quant à la hausse de l'Anglo American Nile, elle est d'un, comme on le sait du reste, k l'annonce officielle de sa fusion avec la Ham- burg America Line,

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by thé Florio- Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESS1NA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charm- ing and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at whicH*to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found ail over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.c. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.c. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovanni degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers "of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday dunng the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steam- ers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive tool will take you on to Capri. From Naples to ROATE is a train journey of but five hours. Ail who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings yon to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its Surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing inte- rest, whilst the local promenades and excur- sions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallom- brosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog- wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view. PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made. in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset. VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most an- eient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuarv, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated médié- val churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the in- comparable Campo Santo filled with-its won- derful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN isa good centre for Northern Italy before making the tone of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful Windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monu- mental cemetery are also worth a visit. Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and-a- half from Milan is SALSOMAG- GIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-ho' r you are at Salsomaggiore.
NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.

VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular tram strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and ye* there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea- port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, bore of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Cam- paniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes. COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake*is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the snore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A Steam train runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two*and- three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland the heart of Europe has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charm- ingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino and M. Generoso. LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town.is worth a visit, as it contains interest- ing paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and ''The Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion. LUCERNE.—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.

In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous. The Like of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgen- stock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can-be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature. BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

A delightful excursion from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand ; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERLAND.—INTER- LAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous 'waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelback and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindehwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft. above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in -Summer and Winter.
GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.

Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co. If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens. It is worth while to spend a *few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
